content.text_entry: The procedure, risks, and benefits of spinal biopsy were discussed with the patient and informed consent obtained. The patient was positioned prone on the biplane angio-suite table. The skin was cleaned and draped in a sterile manner.
After successful biopsy of the lesion the needle was removed and hemostasis obtained by applying light pressure over the puncture site.
content.selection: Core biopsies were sent to pathology | Core biopsies were sent to microbiology | Core biopsies were sent to pathology and microbiology |
There were no perioperative complications |
Succesful bone biopsy |

content.text_entry: The procedure, risks, and benefits of kyphoplasty were discussed with the patient and informed consent obtained. IV antibiotic therapy was administered prior to starting the procedure. The patient was positioned prone on the biplane angio-suite table. The skin was cleaned and draped in a sterile manner.

multi_select.label: Type and approximate amount of local anaesthesia at each level

dropdown.label: Type
dropdown.print_text_after: was injected in to the subcutaneous tissues and deepened with a spinal needle to the periosteum overlying the pedicles

content.text_entry: When the PMMA bone cement had polymerised the needles were removed. The skin was cleaned and dressing applied. There were no immediate complications identified. The patient tolerated the procedure well with no respiratory problems. Anesthesia was reversed and the patient transferred to PACU prior to returning to Day Surgery for discharge.
content.selection: Successful kyphoplasty without complication |

content.text_entry: The risks of the procedure included failure to recanalize vasculature, worsening of occlusion, intracranial hemorrhage, vascular dissection or tear, access site bleeding/complications, and the possibility of catastrophic brain injury from the procedure.
content.selection: Consent was obtained from the patient | Consent on basis of best interest of patient
Manual compression was used to achieve haemostasis. | An angioseal device was used to achieve groin haemostasis. | A pneumatic compression band was used to achieve wrist haemostasis.
There were no periprocedural complications.

multi_select.dropdown: metastatic compression fracture | osteoporotic compression fracture | compression fracture secondary to radiation therapy |

content.selection: Neurolept and local | General anaesthesia |
content.text_entry: The procedure, risks, and benefits of sacroplasty were discussed with the patient and informed consent obtained. IV antibiotic therapy was administered prior to starting the procedure. The patient was positioned prone on the biplane angio-suite table. The skin was cleaned and draped in a sterile manner. Xpert CT and biplane fluoroscopy was employed to guide needle insertion. 5 cc xylocaine/marcaine local anesthetic mix was infiltrated into the skin at the puncture site and deepened with a spinal needle to the periosteum at the targeted location.
content.selection: There were no perioperative complications |
content.text_entry: When the PMMA bone cement had polymerised the needles were removed. The skin was cleaned and dressing applied. There were no immediate complications identified. The patient tolerated the procedure well with no respiratory problems. Anesthesia was reversed and the patient transferred to PACU prior to returning to Day Surgery for discharge.
content.selection: Successful sacroplasty without complication |

content.text_entry: Anteroposterior and lateral projections obtained.
